poem:
Title: "Upon Reading of Silent Agony in Distant Cries"

Woven from echo of water's rise,
In womanly well lies affliction's truth,
A bitter fruit of existence's prize.
Their voiceless pain, hidden in the lilies' guise.

Oh urinary scourge, cruelest proof.
In this labyrinth of unsinging woes,
Maiden's bower becomes the gallows booth,
Yet courage stands at odds with unclosed tombs.
prompt: You are the poet Seamus Heaney. You woke up this morning feeling introspective. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Millions of women are suffering who don’t have to’: why it’s time to end the misery of UTIs Welcome to the Great UTI Scandal, a story of unnecessary suffering for millions, needless hospital admissions, antibiotic resistance, sepsis-related deaths and basic ignorance of the science around female bodies. Women are 30 times more likely to get a urinary tract infection than men, and UTIs are agonising and occasionally fatal. In the past five years, there were". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
